abstract.p: Deborah Frost letter on Anita Gates' May 14 travel article on New York City locations made famous by movies; notes waiter at Jim McMullen's played by Dustin Hoffman in Tootsie can see apartment building where Hoffman lived as previous character in Kramer vs Kramer; photo (S)

block.p: To the Editor: As a native New Yorker, I'm fascinated by the way so many public intersections are not only private landmarks that note significant phases of my own life but have also, courtesy of Hollywood, burned themselves into the collective cultural consciousness. So I particularly enjoyed Anita Gates's ''Bright Lights, Big City . . . Action!'' (May 14) and her efforts to catalog New York scenes that have resonated with many otherwise unrelated people well beyond the city limits.

To the Editor: As a native New Yorker, I'm fascinated by the way so many public intersections are not only private landmarks that note significant phases of my own life but have also, courtesy of Hollywood, burned themselves into the collective cultural consciousness. So I particularly enjoyed Anita Gates's ''Bright Lights, Big City . . . Action!'' (May 14) and her efforts to catalog New York scenes that have resonated with many otherwise unrelated people well beyond the city limits.

Here is one of my favorite New York movie ironies: the waiter at Jim McMullen's played by Dustin Hoffman in the beginning of ''Tootsie'' can look right up from work to the apartment building where the actor lived as a previous character in ''Kramer vs. Kramer.''
